results.title: Silent legacy
results.creator_credit: Debbie Gittens, Brian Beaton, ScreenWest, ATSIC, NIMAA and Reel Images
results.brief_description: The filmmaker’s personal narrative of her father’s experience as one of the stolen generation and his search for identity as an adult. Harry Carmody was taken from his mother’s arms to live a white life at the Church of Christ’s Norsman Mission an event that continues to have far-reaching consequences for his family.

results.title: Photographic memory: a portrait of Mervyn Bishop
results.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Penny McDonald and Chili Films
results.brief_description: A documentary about the life and photography of Mervyn Bishop, one of Australia’s leading indigenous professional photographers who broke new ground during the 1960’s and 1970’s as a media photographer. Bishop’s extensive archive of photographs offer an invaluable document of aspects of Australian and Aboriginal life over the past 40 years.

results.title: Go to jail
results.creator_credit: Lin Buckfield and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This program discusses the impacts of decisions by the Northern Territory and Western Australian governments to introduce mandatory sentencing for juveniles. The laws have caused a storm of protest from civil rights advocates who view mandatory sentencing as an attack on young Aboriginals, who make up over 70 percent of people charged with offences in the Northern Territory. The fact that trivial and first offenders are punished by jail terms is the main driver of discontent. Acknowledgement is made that mandatory sentencing does not work, that there is a high amount of recidivism and that it can be the cause of deaths in custody. Includes interviews with members of the Aboriginal communities, magistrates, prison officers and Hazel Lallara, the grandmother of a 15 year-old who hanged himself whilst in custody. Reporter: Liz Jackson.

results.title: The Wik, the law & the land
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Latham and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
The Labor Government’s Native Title Bill was passed in December 1993, acknowledging the entitlement of the Aboriginal people, in accordance with their laws and customs, to their traditional lands. The High Court’s Wik decision in 1996 removed long held assumptions about land tenure in Australia and created uncertainty in the minds of pastoralists and miners. Aboriginal groups however, believed that the decision would have little impact and that the farmers were generally over-reacting. Co-existence in the form of upgraded land tenure for the pastoralists and traditional access to the land for the Aborigines could lead to long-term stability - at least that was the aim of the Cape York Agreement. The Federal Government under the leadership of John Howard, found itself coming increasingly under pressure from the National Farmers Federation to nullify the High Court’s judgement and extinguish native title. This program examines the issues. Reporter: Murray McLaughlin.

results.title: Shimmer in the city
results.creator_credit: Amanda Hickey and Special Broadcasting Service Corporation
results.brief_description: A detailed look at urban Aboriginal art through interviews with artists, national and international curators, art dealers and art critics, and their views on the place of the work in relation to traditional Aboriginal art as well as Australian society at large. The notion of preconceived ideas of Aboriginal art is discussed as well as the non-stereotypical aboriginality represented in the urban artist’s work where mythical, cultural and environmental heritage is referred to, but situated politically as a confrontation of past and present issues effecting indigenous Australians. Through the interviews with the artists and critics of their work the autobiographical nature of the art is evoked, underlining both the personal and broad social relevance of the art to contemporary Aboriginal experience. It is thorough documentary on the broad spectrum of work being produced that also raises the key issues of Aboriginal ownership of imagery and the question of Aboriginal copyright.

results.title: 100 years: the Australian story
results.creator_credit: Deborah Masters, Sue Spencer and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: A documentary of Australia, one of the world’s oldest democracies, this extensive and thorough series traces Australian political history. Themes of empire, independence, multiculturalism and indigenous Australia make up this enlightening series. Politicians, activists, experts and everyday Australians contributed to this powerful, educational documentary.

results.title: Black Australia
results.creator_credit: Darrell Sibosado, Michael Brogan and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
Film and video segments relevant to this topic have been selected with original footage accompanied by original soundtracks. This program represents aspects of Aboriginal culture in Australia, and focuses on Aboriginal identity. The program uses the unifying symbols found in what is now known as the Aboriginal flag. The three colours in the flag symbolise the Aboriginal way of perceiving: red (land and politics), black (identity and self determination), and yellow (art and spirituality). These three interlinked themes are explored in the film with a focus on stimulating deeper understanding by white Australia on Aboriginality, the attitudes of white Australians towards Aboriginal people, racism in Australia, both individual and institutional and the changes needed in attitude and action to achieve justice. Teacher’s Guide included. Presented by Annette Shun Wah. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Darrell Sibosado, Michael Brogan and Film Australia

results.title: Sydney celebration: the opening ceremony 2000
results.brief_description: At sunset on Friday, September 15 2000, approximately 100,00 spectators (over 4 billion viewers worldwide) and over 12,000 performers celebrated the opening of the 27th Olympiad in Sydney, Australia. Ric Birch, Director of Ceremonies, and David Atkins, the artistic director, produced an epic pageant of Australian culture, from stockmen on horseback to an Aboriginal Corroboree and clan members representing the original Australians, an homage to our sea-loving nature to the modern dance numbers which represented current Australian lifestyles and attitudes. The ceremony concluded with the Olympic torch being borne around the Olympic stadium by a succession of female athletes, acknowledging 100 years of women’s participation in the Olympics, culminating with the Olympic flame being lit by Aboriginal track star Cathy Freeman.

results.title: How black is black
results.creator_credit: Jade Woods, SBS-TV, LOUD Media Festival of Youth Culture and the Arts and Eat Carpet
results.brief_description: How much Aboriginal are you?, we are asked by a group of indigenous Australian children. “How black is black” questions the issue of blackness and how much Aboriginality is assumed to be an issue of skin colour. Through a series of stills and colourful action sequences, thirteen year old director Jade Woods presents a film about identity, friendship and race. Soundtrack provided by the Sisters Underground.

results.title: What have you done with my country
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Douglass Baglin and Cinetel Film Production Services
results.brief_description: Shows what has happened to the land of the first Australians after the Europeans found it and settled it less than 200 years ago. It deliberates on the present state of the Aborigines who have no rights to land and whose culture is overshadowed by the white man’s. Includes readings from Kath Walker’s “We are going”, archival drawings of early European settlement, historical newsreel footage (Vietnam moratorium marches, mining and minerals boom, technological and industrial development etc.) Also emphasises the devastation to the animal world through man’s continual development of the natural environment for commercial gain. Photography by Douglass Baglin, narrated by Tim Elliott.
